channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-13093] Local mode HBase instance doesn't shut down.
item.description:
bin/start-hbase.sh
bin/stop-hbase.sh

That hangs forever. Here's the jstacks:

2015-02-24 16:37:55

item.summary: Local mode HBase instance doesn't shut down.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Looks like HashedWheelTimer in AsyncRpcClient uses Executors#defaultThreadFactory which in turn non-daemon. That can happen if some timeout was not canceled. Jurriaan Mous, can you take a look, can that be related to some not canceled timeout? thanks.

Proposed changes are:
1. use HashedWheelTimer one instance per client, don't use static member with uncontrolled threads in it
2. close this timer whenever client closed
3. give meaningful name to tread pools
4. use threadpool with daemon threads for timers too
Not sure that we need to go away from the static member. It's nice to have a shared thread pool rather than spinning up tons of threads.

May be it better to have additional parameter for user specified thread pool?

But thats ok to revert that back, but pass nonDaemon thread factory for static HashedWheelTimer.
Lets try that way.

making HWT static back (but hide it).
HWT created with its own daemon thread pool
+1 from me.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12700638/HBASE-13093.patch
against master branch at commit d34620b8b661b17d55dd75d24e56c5a7ee661b4e.
ATTACHMENT ID: 12700638

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.
+1 hadoop versions. The patch compiles with all supported hadoop versions (2.4.1 2.5.2 2.6.0)

Patch looks good to me.

It is recommended by HashedWheelTimer to only use one per application so that is why it was static.
http://netty.io/4.0/api/io/netty/util/HashedWheelTimer.html
Jurriaan Mous thanks for reviewing. It seems that yes, HWT should be static.
unable to reproduce TestClientNoCluster failure, it passes locally.
retry
